q: What should I do if I have a lump on my eyelid or swollen, sticky, itchy, or painful eyelids?
a: If you have any of these eyelid problems, you can try treating them yourself by using cleaning solutions for sticky eyelids or over-the-counter allergy medications. However, if your symptoms worsen or last a long time, or if you are in a lot of pain or discomfort, it's best to see a GP for further evaluation and advice.

q: What are the possible causes of a lump or swelling on the eyelid?
a: A lump or swelling on the eyelid can be caused by a stye or chalazion. It's important to see a GP for a proper diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

q: How can a pharmacist help with eyelid problems?
a: A pharmacist can provide guidance on self-treatment options for common eyelid problems and recommend cleaning solutions for sticky eyelids. They can also advise if you need to be seen by an optician or GP.

q: When should I see a GP for an eyelid problem?
a: You should see a GP if you are worried about your eyelid problem, if your symptoms worsen or last a long time, if your eyelid is painful or causes a lot of discomfort, or if you have yellow lumps or patches around your eyes.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for an eyelid problem?
a: If your swollen eyelid is red, hot, painful, tender, or blistered, if your eyelid droops suddenly, if you experience pain in your eye (not just your eyelid), if the white of your eye is very red, if you're sensitive to light, if your eyesight changes, if you have a very high temperature, if you think it's an allergic reaction, or if you feel generally unwell, it is important to ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: Can over-the-counter medications help with itchy, flaky, sticky, or swollen eyelids?
a: Yes, over-the-counter allergy medications can provide relief for itchy, flaky, sticky, or swollen eyelids. However, if the symptoms persist or worsen, it is advisable to consult a GP for proper evaluation and treatment.

q: What causes a yellow lump or patch on the eyelid?
a: A yellow lump or patch on the eyelid can be caused by a condition called xanthelasma, which is sometimes associated with high cholesterol levels. It is recommended to consult a GP for accurate diagnosis and management.

q: How can I treat eyelid problems myself?
a: You can try self-treatment for common eyelid problems by using cleaning solutions for sticky eyelids and over-the-counter allergy medications. However, if the problems persist or worsen, it is important to seek medical advice from a GP.

q: What should I do if my eyelid droops suddenly?
a: If your eyelid droops suddenly, it is recommended to seek urgent medical advice from a GP or get help from NHS 111. They can evaluate the underlying cause and provide appropriate treatment.

q: What are the possible causes of a hot, painful, and swollen eyelid?
a: A hot, painful, and swollen eyelid can be a symptom of cellulitis. It is important to seek urgent medical advice from a GP or get help from NHS 111 for proper evaluation and treatment.

q: What should I do if I have a lump on my eyelid?
a: If you have a lump on your eyelid, it is important to see a GP for proper diagnosis and treatment. They can determine the cause of the lump and provide appropriate treatment or referral if necessary.

q: Can a pharmacist help with eyelid problems?

q: When should I see a GP for an eyelid problem?
a: You should see a GP if you are worried about an eyelid problem, if your symptoms are getting worse or lasting a long time, if your eyelid is painful or causing a lot of discomfort, or if you have yellow lumps or patches around your eyes.

q: What should I do if my swollen eyelid is red, hot, and painful?
a: If your swollen eyelid is red, hot, and painful, it is important to seek urgent medical attention. You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or call NHS 111. These symptoms may indicate an infection or other serious condition.

q: What are the possible causes of a lump or swelling on the eyelid?
a: A lump or swelling on the eyelid can be caused by a stye, chalazion, allergy, blepharitis, conjunctivitis, xanthelasma, ectropion, entropion, or cellulitis. It is best to consult a GP for proper diagnosis and treatment.

q: Should I self-diagnose if I have an eyelid problem?
a: No, it is not recommended to self-diagnose an eyelid problem. If you have any concerns, it is important to see a GP who can properly assess your symptoms and provide appropriate medical advice or treatment.

q: What should I do if my eyelid droops suddenly?
a: If your eyelid droops suddenly, it is advisable to seek urgent medical attention. You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or call NHS 111. Sudden eyelid drooping may require further evaluation by a healthcare professional.

q: When should I call NHS 111 for help with an eyelid problem?
a: You should call NHS 111 or get help from 111 online if your swollen eyelid is red, hot, painful, tender, or blistered, if the pain is in your eye (not just the eyelid), if the white of your eye is very red, if your eyesight changes, if you experience a very high temperature or feel generally unwell, or if you suspect it's an allergic reaction.

q: What can a pharmacist recommend for itchy and swollen eyelids?
a: A pharmacist can provide recommendations on how to treat itchy and swollen eyelids. They may suggest over-the-counter options such as antihistamine eye drops or lubricating eye drops. If the symptoms persist or worsen, it is advisable to consult a GP.

q: Can mild eyelid problems go away on their own?
a: Yes, many mild eyelid problems, such as a lump that goes away after 3 or 4 weeks or mildly itchy, flaky, or sticky eyelids that clear up by themselves, can resolve without medical intervention. However, if the symptoms persist or worsen, it is best to consult a healthcare professional.
